discourse_list.title: \xf0\x9f\x94\x91 Should we burn the admin keys? An argument for minting MKR

content.content: Is Maker complete? Are we done improving the Protocol? Should we burn the admin keys and let Maker run its course? Hypergrowth Some of us believe that we are just getting started, that Maker is ripe for hypergrowth, precisely what we want to achieve. The MKR we’re asking for is no different than a startup raising Series A. Yes, it will dilute the token holders, but the goal of that dilution is the sought hypergrowth. The Slippery Slope Argument “Minting MKR is a slippery slope.” Governance will (arguably) always have the power to mint more tokens. A Decentralized Maximalist might argue that having the admin key to change the code is the beginning of the slippery slope. The slippery slope argument sounds more like a motion of no-confidence towards Governance. And it’s by no means invalid. But if we do not trust Governance, we should frame it that way. The Social Contract MKR is burnt when things are going well and minted when needed. These needs might vary:  recover bad debt (we’ve seen this in the past) raise funds to grow (we’ve also seen this in the past; that’s why we have investors)  It seems that we have forgotten the second need. The Market Value of Valuable Contributors Every single worker has a market value. Right now, the industry dictates that a given person will earn a given amount that might seem fair or not. For example, there is no shortage of projects that will take any Maker developer without blinking before lunchtime. Should every contributor get MKR tokens? Maybe not. We will need to decide as a Community how much we want to align to the industry and how much we choose to override. Base Salary versus Bonus Most have agreed that the “base salary” should come from the surplus buffer to provide job security for the Maker contributors; some argue that any “bonus” should not. Usually, a worker will look at their total compensation package and decide if that is competitive or not. You can name each piece of the compensation however you want, but removing certainty to any of those parts will make the deal less attractive. An extreme implementation of that argument could hold that we should only pay minimum wage to our employees. Anything above that is a bonus that the contributor should only get if the Protocol is faring well. Making the total compensation package less certain will make our offers less competitive and hinder our capacity to attract talent. We should be worried about attracting the wrong talent: that is the actual slippery slope. If they are only here for the money, then… I have also heard that money should not be the primary factor for hiring someone. I think we all agree on that one. However, this should not mean that we need to underpay our contributors — much less not pay them at all. I don’t want any core contributor to consider an external offer because we are not competitive. How about if instead of minting we… We need MKR that is readily available to compensate people. Minting seems to be the easiest, direct answer to solve this need. Any other creative solution seems to carry risks of slippage, front-running, or both. What’s more, there might be risks attached to using elements such as the Surplus Buffer for things that are not intended. Things To Agree Should we burn the admin keys? First, we will need to agree on what type of project we are. Is this it? Have we achieved maturity? Do we let the burn bring value to the token holders? Should we consider burning the keys and ensure that Governance cannot change this (the code is the law) ? Do we want (hyper)growth? We need to decide if we want hypergrowth. To raise the required capital (MKR), we will need to mint. As an option, we might want to choose to be a bootstrapped project and only use the money we get from revenues. If that is the case, we need to be clear upfront about it and let contributors decide if they want to stay in a project with this constraint. Do we want an overarching framework? We probably don’t want to have this same discussion every time a Core Unit comes up with some compensation scheme. Ideally, we can agree on something that we can reuse (and review from time to time). Framing a Framework General Framework   Do we align with the industry and compensate with tokens (MKR)?   What is the best way of obtaining these tokens? (reduce slippage, avoid front-running, etc.)   Do we want to include a vesting period, a cliff, and weighting (you get more on your fourth year than in your first)?   How often should we review this framework?   etc.   Specific Framework   Which teams/contributors get MKR tokens?   How much MKR should they get?   etc.   Edge Cases   What happens when a contributor changes Core Units?   etc.   Next Steps Discussion We will have a Community Call on Wednesday, 31st, to discuss these topics. Working Group We will probably need to form a working group to tackle this issue and present a decent framework to the Community and teams. Please write to me if you’re interested.  Bonus: a diagram How much are we minting?  Minting Perspective1478×764 92.6 KB  If:  100 contributors (will we have that many?) at the suggested 0.1% rate (most will get less) stay for four years (turnover suggests it will be less)  Then we would be minting 10% of the total supply.  Edit: added link to the call.

content.content: @amyjung @juan Thank you for the clarification. I will continue this discussion in good faith.

This was very well laid out @juan. I was against minting from mostly just a PR perspective, in that I didn’t want people vaguely familiar w/ Maker to look at us and dismiss MKR because we were diverting away from the deflationary value proposition. But at a certain point why should I let an uniformed opinion about MKR dictate the course of action? We should pursue what has the best chance to continue and extend Maker dominance in the crypto-credit space. To that end, it’s pretty illogical to throw up fundamental objections to minting. We’ve seen the MKR token over 4x in value in the last few months, perhaps we should be looking to companies like Tesla who capitalized on market perception by printing a budget. The buy and burn model can still be at the core of what we’re building here, but especially at the true start of the DAO era I’ve come around to the idea of minting. Decades from now I think MKR holders will be much better off because we decided to fund our growth fully up to needs rather than an arbitrary revenue projection.     juan:  We’re growing pretty well already because the Foundation is paying the tab.   This is a pretty huge point that I ignored in my gut reaction to MKR minting. Without minting our “warchest” is just what has been diverted to the SB, and from a risk perspective we really don’t want to be drawing down that number. We’ve appreciated all this growth because the Foundation had the ability to sell MKR into the market (not that different than minting when you think about it) and that has lead to us hitting nearly 3B DAI and and over 100M in annualized SFs. We should absolutely take caution when making the decision to inflate MKR, but as Juan so eloquently pointed out here, assuming we wouldn’t take caution is the same as saying we don’t have faith in Governance to do the right thing in the future. If that’s the case, as someone looking to take on a serious role w/ GovAlpha, I’d love to hear the concerns and what we can do to strengthen faith in Governance.

content.content: Here is what I wrote to @SebVentures in Rocket Chat PM and would essentially be my proposal/opinion for MKR minting: I think the biggest thing is making sure MKR is still deflationary long term and making sure we all agree to this philosophy. So short term it’s ok if we mint a bit for incentives but overall we should ensure that the supply is still going down. I think whoever can come up with a solid proposal that addresses these issues will garner a lot of support. So we have to define what is an acceptable amount of minting based on current and projected revenues vs MKR price appreciation. It’s a bit of guess work but as long as we stay conservative with the minting we should be ok. For instance we can estimate that MKR burn would be at a minimum 1-3% annually and then if we know Core Unit expenses we can get to a rough number of MKR we can accept as minting so that we are still net deflationary. So lets say revenues EoY are 200M, Core Unit expenses are 20M, and price of MKR is 5k. So Revenues are 180M/5K MKR = 36k MKR to be burned. Let’s ignore surplus buffer for this calculation as long term I don’t think it matters in price calculation. So you have ~3.6% deflation and we agree to mint 10% of that or 3600 to be split between Core Units and other incentive programs for the next year. This is obviously just an example of the possibilities. Know that I have no idea how much expenses are going to be and so could be more than 100M. These are just rough guesses for illustrative purposes. Next you’d need to agree to the allocation of these MKR based on Core Unit importance or perhaps during the budget proposal the Core Units know how much is allocated by governance and can then vie for a percentage of the pot knowing that certain Core Units “deserve” more. Something along those lines. Alternatively, governance agreeing to a yearly inflation of x% for incentives and then Core Units vying for that may be a simpler option.

content.content: If CUs decide they want to pay their employees in MKR, we could give them a bag of Dai and let them buy it off the open market, or we can mint the equivalent amount and let it be used for compensation. I think the latter option is strictly preferable to us than wasting a bunch of money on slippage due to a misunderstanding of the token’s social contract. If expenses is greater than incomes, the MKR token is inflationary. If incomes are greater than expenses, then it is deflationary. This is how the system has always been designed to work. If personnel costs are some reasonable amount, the token will continue to deflate over time. If personnel costs are significantly more than revenues, then I guess something has gone very wrong.

content.content: Some very good points in this thread. Thanks to everyone that participates and @juan for launching the party. I will mainly summarize what I understood and fill in some holes. One important point is the idea to have a limited budget for workforce expenses. This is probably for the best. This provides a constraint and incentivizes Core Unit to limit their size to the best efficiency. Let’s say Governance decides to allocate $50M to the workforce for the near future (one year). This can be split into 25M DAI and 12k MKR. The DAI part would be the base salary (defined using market price). The MKR part could be allocated using a split where every worker has a weight on it (contributor vs facilitator, core core unit vs non-core core unit, …). This removes the MKR minting issue more or less. Governance has decided to an annual budget and if earnings are not enough, well you end up with a net MKR issuance. You can decide to express everything in DAI as well and said the equity part is $25M to be split no matter the price of MKR. There are pros and cons. It’s not super important. I personally prefer the MKR option as a Core Unit facilitator and as a MKR holder. You get/pay more if MKR increase but that also good for MKR holders. And it decreases the cost/dilution if there is a DeFi winter. The base budget (the first 25M DAI) is a limit for Governance to not spend too much and agree on everything (even if only a gentleman agreement), the second part is a fixed incentive that avoids the complexity of managing MKR issuance. I think this is fair to everyone.

@juan, I love what you do, and your post is definitely stirring the pot here. If anything, I view this post as a “Devil’s Advocate.” This conversation must be had. A lot has already been said on this topic, so I’ll try to cover some of what I think is worth considering.  First, where I stand:  We NEED to be competitive to retain talent. I am pro-vesting. Compensating devs/contributors w/ vested MKR, A LOT of MKR, is a must.  Crude as it was, @kevinwildenradt and I did propose MIP42.   Minting is not inherently evil. I am vehemently against minting without strict, clearly defined, codified constraints.  What I mean is, minting beyond the point of dilution.   Minting to dilution is a non-starter for me.  I will vote against it.   We need a clearly defined CU standardized framework, even if it means delaying the rollout of CUs. Vesting MKR should be voted on by the DAO for how much each CU receives.  I hope we are adult enough to not battle over scraps of who gets how much and can calmly accept the Maker governance community’s decisions.   MKR for vesting should ideally be set aside and reserved for CU teams ahead of their respective launches, likely open to monthly/quarterly/annual review. From where and how we obtain that MKR is the open debate.  @SebVentures G-Sheet is awesome.   So, I have a few key premises:  People suck. Humans have cognitive biases. MKR governance is composed of people. The printer button’s temptation is too powerful for any mere mortal to resist.  I do not care who you are… if the printer button is there, you will press it. No one, no matter their willpower or moral alignment, will resist the printer button on an indefinite timeline. We will come up with any and every "reasonable" justification to use it. Grow the team, retain talent, fund development, form partnerships… you name it. I don’t have an issue with minting per se. If, from a technical, market standpoint, it makes more sense to mint rather than use the surplus to acquire MKR and redistribute. So be it. The issue, as I see it, is minting freely to incentivize “promises” of future growth… and minting above our means (i.e., minting more than we burn) hoping that the growth incentivized by minting will outpace the dilution effect. This path has already been traveled. We know where it leads. I will argue this point til death. We are all human at the end of the day and are all susceptible to the typical cognitive biases that come with that. We need a system with a proper incentive structure that does not allow for bad (or stupid) actors to be able to make bad decisions. We need to think hard for another way. We must set strict constraints and work within those bounds. If we lose some talent as a result, it will be a tragedy, but I would much rather we retain the talent that is passionate about Maker and understands the power and future of MakerDAO.  We are the industry leader and the role model for the entire space. We must lead by example.  If we choose to go down the path of unrestricted minting for XYZ, we WILL devolve into a mess where everyone will be looking to vote for themselves to receive minted MKR in one way or another. I, myself, will become a proponent of minting. If we are minting… I WANT IN. You better be printing to me for staking my vote. You better print to me for any and every reason. Fuck those ppl who aren’t participating. Snooze, you lose… but you better print to ME!  This is NOT who I am at heart, but that’s what this incentive structure will lead me to become.  I am largely with @Planet_X:  I am not suggesting Maker has reached this stage yet, and I am not an anti-print maximalist, but any printing of MKR will need to come hand in hand with countermeasures to hinder future printing for any other reason than to keep the protocol above water. It is very hard to be just a little bit pregnant.   The Big Unanswered Question: The Future of The Foundation Treasury This remains the largest unanswered question, and imo, is perhaps one of the most important factors for this discussion. I fully understand that this is a touchy subject, and for legal reasons, we may not know the answer for a while. As touchy as it may be… the time has come to touch it. Once the foundation dissolves:  Will the MKR be burned?  Then we can freely mint up to the burn amount, reserve that MKR for the DAO treasury, and ration out MKR as needed for years to come. The minting issue becomes moot.   Will the MKR be transferred to the DAO treasury?  We can reserve that MKR and ration out MKR as needed for years to come. The minting issue becomes moot.   Will the MKR be donated?  No idea what to do in this case.   Will the MKR be disbursed to friends and foundation members?  I’d rate the odds of that at near-zero… but again, no idea what to do in this case.   Will the MKR be disbursed equally to all MKR holders after some snapshot?  Maybe this puts us back to a minting against revenue scenario.   Will the MKR be disbursed equally to all MKR holders that have locked their MKR in the voting contract after some snapshot?  Maybe this puts us back to a minting against revenue scenario.   Will there be some other plans for that MKR?  We’ll have to see what happens and adapt accordingly.    Depending on how this unfolds, we may have to completely readjust all of our plans for minting and vesting schedules.  TLDR:  Let’s not be irresponsible. Let’s pause and think about whether or how much we really truly need to be minting. I know this is a hard transition. We are all strong, intelligent, and passionate pioneers. We can get by without abusing the printer button. Resist the temptation at all costs. The entire industry is looking up to us. Let’s set the right example. Let’s not repeat the same mistakes that have plagued the traditional world for millennia.   Side Note:  I have no idea what burning the admin keys entails, so I won’t place a strong opinion there. That said, intuitively, it doesn’t seem like the play. content.content: The snapshot you posted is incredibly misleading - I don’t think it was deliberate but it’s from last year and outstanding shares can fluctuate over short periods of time.  However, the long term trend in Apple’s share repurchases is clear.  Apple shares outstanding for the quarter ending December 31, 2020 were 17.114B, a 3.96% decline year-over-year. Apple 2020 shares outstanding were 17.528B, a 5.74% decline from 2019. Apple 2019 shares outstanding were 18.596B, a 7.02% decline from 2018. Apple 2018 shares outstanding were 20B, a 4.79% decline from 2017.  A company’s decision to buy back shares is completely separate from the stock compensation employees receive and is based on capital allocation. If a company is buying their own shares back, it is because they believe it is providing the highest ROI vs alternatives, namely reinvesting in the base business. If executives and employees are receiving stock compensation, it is because the value they bring to the business exceeds such costs which the market dictates.  Amazon shares outstanding for the quarter ending December 31, 2020 were 0.510B, a 1.19% increase year-over-year. Amazon 2020 shares outstanding were 0.51B, a 1.19% increase from 2019. Amazon 2019 shares outstanding were 0.504B, a 0.8% increase from 2018. Amazon 2018 shares outstanding were 0.5B, a 1.42% increase from 2017.  Looking purely at the buy backs/dilutions for these companies, one would assume Apple outperformed Amazon.  AAPL v AMZN1111×518 81 KB  Let’s take this a step further and look at an extreme example. For the prior three years revenue growth for CVNA has been 42%, 101%, and 128% respectively. The dilution is reflected below. How have shareholders done over this period, where revenue and share growth have both been quite high?  Carvana shares outstanding for the quarter ending December 31, 2020 were 0.065B, a 38.71% increase year-over-year. Carvana 2020 shares outstanding were 0.065B, a 38.71% increase from 2019. Carvana 2019 shares outstanding were 0.047B, a 55.93% increase from 2018. Carvana 2018 shares outstanding were 0.03B, a 97.12% increase from 2017.   CVNA vs AMZN and APPL1133×519 83.8 KB  Carvana is a used car platform, with very high fixed and capital costs. They are currently no where near profitability and analysts do not expect them to reach profitability for 3-5 years. I post these to illustrate that investment returns are not dictated by a decision to buy back from or dilute shareholders, but long term free cash flow which is derived from effective capital allocation. I understand that Maker was built and intended to be net deflationary over time. This is great in theory and long-term is an ideal model in my opinion, but only when MakerDAO’s growth has slowed and the expected ROI from the buy-back exceeds all other investment and capital allocation opportunities.

content.content: Maker needs a treasury of DAI to weather a downturn in the market/DeFi Winter and ensure CU’s can continue to be paid without needing to issue MKR (which would be at undesirable prices in the aforementioned scenario). This would be separate from the Surplus Buffer and would be invested to generate a return. We would have to model out annual expenses and worst case scenarios to determine how much of a treasury to carry, but in my opinion this is an easy win to provide stability to CU’s and ensure MKR doesn’t get minted at low prices/unfavorable market conditions.

content.content: Aight @aburban90 you tagged me, so here are some comments.     aburban90:  So, I have a few key premises:  People suck. Humans have cognitive biases. MKR governance is composed of people. The printer button’s temptation is too powerful for any mere mortal to resist.    Only two of these are correct.  People suck - No they don’t, on average humans cooperate more often than they defect. If this wasn’t true, civilisation wouldn’t exist. Humans have cognitive biases - Yes. MKR governance is composed of people. - Yes. The printer button’s temptation is too powerful for any mere mortal to resist. - Eh, I disagree, but no one mortal has the ability to push it, so it’s more or less beside the point.      aburban90:  No one, no matter their willpower or moral alignment, will resist the printer button on an indefinite timeline.   No one mortal has the ability to push it. What matters is whether multiple mortals can convince each other that it is a good idea.     aburban90:  and minting above our means (i.e., minting more than we burn) hoping that the growth incentivized by minting will outpace the dilution effect. This path has already been traveled. We know where it leads.   This choice is always a gamble. It can end well, it can end badly. It depends on the usage of the funds, but it isn’t inherently a bad choice, it is a risky choice. No one knows where it leads in any individual instance until it leads there.     aburban90:  We must set strict constraints and work within those bounds.   We cannot set hard-coded constraints. Governance cannot bind its own future actions in this way from a technical standpoint - not in a way that allows the protocol to still operate with MKR as the backstop to the system.     aburban90:  If we choose to go down the path of unrestricted minting for XYZ, we WILL devolve into a mess where everyone will be looking to vote for themselves to receive minted MKR in one way or another.   This is a slippery slope argument that isn’t justified. Why is it unreasonable to say that governance might vote in favour of minting for Core Unit alignment and incentives, but would not vote in favour of minting for individuals? Why is it certain that governance cannot use minting judiciously, especially when it already does so? We’re debating where the line is, not whether or not the line exists. We know there is a line, because we currently mint MKR in order to recapitalize DAI and prevent the death of the protocol. Ultimately there are different ways to die. We might die fast or we might die slow. Minting MKR to recapitalize the system is an example of using MKR mint to prevent dying fast. Minting MKR to pay salaries in DAI (in the absence of other funds) is another example of using MKR mint to prevent dying fast. Dying slow is much harder to see coming, and much harder to reason about, but that doesn’t mean it isn’t a threat. Some tools are dangerous. Often the most useful tools are the most dangerous. Arguing that the tool is so dangerous that we cannot touch it prevents both positive and negative outcomes of its use.

content.content: Holy cow! What a crazy discussion you guys have here over issued and outstanding shares versus fully diluted shares, buybacks, and employee Stock options haha. When a corporation grants someone the right to buy shares later, such as granting a stock option to an employee, those shares are not yet issued and outstanding. Reserved shares are often referred to as the “unallocated option pool” or the “pool.” The unallocated option pool is not considered issued and outstanding. And no, Berkshire Hathaway is not currently buying back stock to Reward/pay employee bonuses. It’s rewarding the shareholders of BRK. All in all it reads as this discussion is not coming up with a solution. Lets keep it simple.
